author: paulmillr
content: Does anybody care about TOR issue besides me? https://twitter.com/paulmillr/status/1559663942124945408

author: .paulharris
content: it's possible that people care, just focusing on a different solution... is there a reason a solution would have to specifically use TOR? Generally statements like 'does anyone care about xxx except me', i see it as clickbait more than anything else...

author: paulmillr
content: <@680234424037670912> Of course, if a solution would be able to resolve issues without TOR, it would be great solution. I’ve mentioned TOR because it’s what other networks utilize. For the title: I monitor the news, EIPs, repositories, ethresearch, etc — lots of talk on data availability sampling, sharding, rollups, pbs, etc. No discussions on a censorship-resistant/anonymous routing. This issue is a huge deal.

author: paulmillr
content: Wanna know who owns the validators? Just listen to consensus gossip for some time and identify server owners (servers were most likely KYC-ed). Wanna know who sent some tx from some node? Just listen to execution gossip. That can be dangerous. It is actively utilized by blockchain analysis companies.

author: .paulharris
content:
my 2c...
In context of framing, I don't see much changing until post merge, but relays etc are on the list for things, which would improve, if not completely solve anonymity...  Censorship is obviously always a huge topic, and particularly present at the moment, so we're not ignoring it, but also fair to say that there's a lot going on right now, it may not be the most present issue to solve...
I think its healthy to ensure we don't lose track of things like this, but equally important that we have priorities etc, as ultimately we don't have unlimited resources...

author: .paulharris
content: keeping in mind that releases for mainnet merge are iminent, within a couple of days

author: paulmillr
content:
Merge is #1 today — no issues here. I’m talking about “the next couple upgrades” timeline, not imminent. This is a thing that could take 3-9 months across all client teams, at least.

People developing software for validators for Raspberry PI — awesome. Where would you host it? At your home? What if you live in a country which actively surveils validators? I know countries that monitor and confiscate mining equipment.

author: .paulharris
content:
its a good time to have the conversation, but I honestly can't predict where it falls in priorities currently in terms of a full scale TOR type concept - keeping in mind that similar solutions for some p2p led to everyone that runs a client being a target, it's a topic I don't think i'd go far into without legal advice to be honest...
All i can say is we're anti-censorship as a stance, and it's something I'd expect that we continue to see steps towards in some way...

author: paulmillr
content: Everyone who runs ETH node/validator would also be a target — with, or without new routing. It’s just a matter of time and location.
